steps.title: What is a Digital Footprint?
steps.content:
Understanding Digital Footprints

Your digital footprint is all the information about you that exists on the internet as a result of your online activity.

Your Digital Footprint Includes:

  • Posts on social media
  • Comments on websites and forums
  • Photos and videos you share
  • Messages and emails
  • Websites you visit
  • Apps you use
  • Online purchases
  • Location data from your devices

quiz.question: Which of these is NOT part of your digital footprint?
options: Photos you share on social media

steps.title: How Do You Leave a Digital Footprint?
steps.content:
Your Online Activities Matter

Common Ways You Create Digital Footprints:

Active Footprints

  • Social media posts
  • Online comments
  • Email communications
  • Blog posts

Passive Footprints

  • Browsing history
  • Search history
  • Cookies stored
  • App usage data

Recommendation Algorithms

Services like Netflix, Spotify, and YouTube track your activity to suggest content:

Netflix

Suggests shows based on your watching history

Spotify

Creates playlists from your music preferences

YouTube

Recommends videos similar to ones you've watched

quiz.question: Which of these creates a passive digital footprint?

steps.title: Understanding Cookies
steps.content:
Website Cookies: Your Online Memory Trail

What are Cookies?

Imagine if every time you visited your favorite game website, you had to start from level 1, or if you had to log in to your email every time you clicked a new message. That would be frustrating! This is where cookies come in - they're like a website's memory that helps remember things about you.

How Cookies Help You:

  • Remember your game progress
  • Keep you logged into websites
  • Save items in your shopping cart
  • Remember your favorite settings

How Long Do They Last?

  • Some disappear when you close your browser (like a shopping cart)
  • Others stay longer to remember your preferences
  • You can clear cookies anytime through your browser settings

How Websites Use Cookies to Show You Ads

Have you ever looked at shoes on one website, then seen ads for those same shoes on other websites? Here's how that works:

  1. You visit a shoe website and look at some cool sneakers
  2. The website saves a cookie saying "this person likes these sneakers"
  3. Other websites can read this cookie
  4. They show you ads for the sneakers you looked at

Your Cookie Choices

When you visit a website, you might see a "Cookie Settings" popup. You can choose:

Required Cookies

Usually the bare minimum the website needs to work properly

Optional Cookies

Usually this is for advertising purposes

steps.title: Why Your Digital Footprint Matters
steps.content:
The Importance of Your Digital Footprint

Your digital footprint can affect:

Future Opportunities

  • Job applications
  • School admissions
  • Volunteer positions
  • Leadership roles

Potential Risks

  • Online reputation
  • Personal privacy
  • Digital security
  • Identity protection

Real-World Example:

In the Behind The News video, Ruby's old posts about disliking ice cream affected her job interview at an ice cream shop. This shows how past online activity can impact future opportunities.

quiz.question: How can a digital footprint affect your future?
options: It can only affect your social media accounts
It has no effect on job applications
It can influence job opportunities and school admissions
It only matters for famous people

steps.title: Creating a Positive Digital Footprint
steps.content:
Building a Positive Online Presence

Best Practices:

Think Before You Post

  • Is it true?
  • Is it kind?
  • Would you say it in person?
  • Would you be happy for anyone to see it?

Protect Your Privacy

  • Use strong privacy settings
  • Don't share personal information
  • Only connect with people you know
  • Be careful with location sharing

quiz.question: What should you consider before posting online?
options: Only if your friends will like it
If it will get many likes
